titleproper.value: Guide to the Julius Wiesenfeld Papers <num>WAG.348</num>

publisher.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

addressline: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

creation.value: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace <date>2019-08-15T15:09:19</date>

corpname.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

extent.value: in 3 manuscript boxes and 1 half manuscript box

abstract.value: Julius "Julie" Wiesenfeld (1913-1979) was a professor of mathematics and union and civil rights advocate. While in Cedar Falls, Wiesenfeld served as the President of the Black Hawk County Union Council, and was active in union, civil rights, and anti-war organizing, helping to organize the UNI chapter of the American Federation of Teachers, and adovcating for amnesty of Vietnam draft resistance while he was a delegate to the State Democratic Convention in 1968 and 1972. The Julius Wiesenfeld Papers (dated approximately 1941-1977) consist of correspondence, writings, and newspaper clippings on a variety of topics related to the Old Left, including labor strikes, union organizing, conflict within the Socialist Labor Party of America, voting rights and voting registration efforts in the 1960s, opposition to American involvement in Vietnam, Marxist theory and history, and international Marxism during the mid-20th century, including the student-led Red Guards in China and de-Stalinisation in the Soviet Union.

p.value: Identification of item, date; Julius Wiesenfeld Papers; WAG 348; box number; folder number or item identifier; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.
There is no documentation concerning the provenance of this collection.
Rod Library, University of Northern Iowa. "Julius Wiesenfled." https://library.uni.edu/collections/special-collections/biographical-sketches/julius-wiesenfeld (retrieved August 15, 2019).

The Julius Wiesenfeld Papers (dated approximately 1941-1977) consist of correspondence, writings, and newspaper clippings on a variety of topics related to the Old Left, including labor strikes, union organizing, conflict within the Socialist Labor Party of America, voting rights and voting registration efforts in the 1960s, the American Veterans Committee and opposition to American involvement in Vietnam, Marxist theory and history, and international Marxism during the mid-20th century, including the student-led Red Guards in China and de-Stalinisation in the Soviet Union. The bulk of the correspondence in this collection is between Wiesenfeld and Abe Levine, the first United Teachers Federation Vice President for elementary schools.

subject.value: Labor unions and socialism -- United States.
